sailpoint.object
Class PolicyViolation

java.lang.Object
  sailpoint.tools.xml.AbstractXmlObject
      sailpoint.object.SailPointObject
          sailpoint.object.PolicyViolation
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, Certifiable, sailpoint.tools.xml.PersistentXmlObject, sailpoint.tools.xml.XMLReferenceTarget
public class PolicyViolation
extends SailPointObject
implements Certifiable, java.lang.Cloneable

A class holding information about one policy violation for an Identity.

See Also:
Serialized Form

Field Detail

ARG_RELEVANT_APPS

public static final java.lang.String ARG_RELEVANT_APPS
Argument for a list of applications relevant to this violation. This is only needed if the violation is not based on entitlements, and you want the violation to show up in application-centric certification reports. Value should be csv.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

ARG_DETAILS

public static final java.lang.String ARG_DETAILS
Argument containing more details about entitlements involved in the policy violation.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

ARG_RISK_WEIGHT

public static final java.lang.String ARG_RISK_WEIGHT
The name of an optional attribute whose value is used by the PolicyScorer as the risk weight for this violation. This is used with custom policies that do not have a GenericConstraints model but which might want to generate different types of violation with different weights.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

isNameUnique

public boolean isNameUnique()
Description copied from class: SailPointObject
Return true if the object name can be used as a unique database key. It is almost always true, but a few classes like SODConstraint want to allow names for lookup, but cannot guarantee that the names are unique.

This is relevant only if hasName is true.

Overrides:
isNameUnique in class SailPointObject

hasName

public boolean hasName()
Description copied from class: SailPointObject
Return true if the object has a name. This is used by the AbstractSailPointObject and the PersistenceManagers to tell if the name can be used in a search filter.

It is almost always true, but a few classes like log records do not have meaningful names. Consider using ObjectUtil.hasName(SailPointContext, Class) instead

Overrides:
hasName in class SailPointObject

getLeftBundles

public java.lang.String getLeftBundles()
For role SOD policies, the name of the roles on the left side that were in conflict. This will be a CSV if there was more than one matching role on the left.

This is relevant only for policies of TYPE_SOD.

setLeftBundles

public void setLeftBundles(java.lang.String names)

addLeftBundle

public void addLeftBundle(java.lang.String name)
Accumulate bundle names as CSVs as they are added. Prevent duplicates.

Parameters:
name - The name of the role to be added

getRightBundles

public java.lang.String getRightBundles()
For role SOD policies, the name of the roles on the right side that were in conflict. This will be a CSV if there was more than one matching role.

This is relevant only for policies of TYPE_SOD.

setRightBundles

public void setRightBundles(java.lang.String names)

Accumulate bundle names as CSVs as they are added. Prevent duplicates.

Parameters:
name - The name of the role to be added

getBundlesMarkedForRemediation

public java.lang.String getBundlesMarkedForRemediation()
For SODConstraints, the names of the bundles (either right or left) that have been marked to be remediated. This is a CSV.

This is relevant only for policies of TYPE_SOD.

setBundlesMarkedForRemediation

public void setBundlesMarkedForRemediation(java.lang.String names)
This is relevant only for policies of TYPE_SOD.

This is relevant only for policies of TYPE_SOD.

public void setBundlesMarkedForRemediation(java.util.List<Bundle> bundles)
This is relevant only for policies of TYPE_SOD.

getMitigator

public java.lang.String getMitigator()
Name of the identity that performed a mitigation on this violation. This should be set by the interrogator to indicate that the violation was mitigated at the time of the policy scan. If you need more information, you will have to find the matching MitigationExpiration from the Identity.

setMitigator

public void setMitigator(java.lang.String name)

getActivityId

public java.lang.String getActivityId()
The unique id of the associated application activity object. This is relevant only for policies of TYPE_ACTIVITY.

setActivityId

public void setActivityId(java.lang.String id)

setAlertable

public void setAlertable(boolean b)

isAlertable

public boolean isAlertable()
A transient flag passed from the PolicyExecutors back to the Interrogator to indicate that notifications and work items need to be opened. Some policies might only choose to do this for severe violations to prevent email explosion.

public void setNotify(boolean b)

getDisplayableName

public java.lang.String getDisplayableName()
                                    throws GeneralException
Get the best displayable name for this violation.

NOTE: This is a holdover from pre-3.0 where the displayable name could come from up to four different places. Now, the constraintName should be used consistently for this.

Throws:
GeneralException
